course.subject: ECON
course.name: Introduction to Econometrics
course.description: Topics on the use of statistical regression techniques in modeling and estimating economic and business relationships. Both theoretical and applied aspects are addressed.
course.prerequisites: One of ISOM 2500, MATH 2411 or MATH 3423

reviews.author: wen moon ser
reviews.title: 浪費4 credits...
reviews.comment_content:
我知個course個個sem開成百幾個位都好多人reg唔到，個個sem都好多唔require呢個course嘅人想reg呢個course，但如果你想學野真係慳返啖氣，可以唔洗reg。順便講埋econ department啲奸招，佢好興臨放位出public enrollment 嘅時候cut位，你唔係Econ major 根本就唔會reg到，所以慳返啖氣轉去讀下MATH2421/ MATH3423/ MATH3424好過。佢個prerequisite 簡直係離晒大譜，MATH2411/MATH3423完全係第二個level嚟，拎嚟做prerequisites。有basic statistics做prerequisites 又要用成個月時間review返啲statistics，成個course有大半係suppose喺prerequisite 到學咗。如果你讀咗MATH2411，midterm前都唔洗上堂架喇，考試仲要有cheatsheet。另外個course focus重喺concepts多過計數同proof，通常啲proofs都唔教架喇，數學廢都唔會死得太慘。呢個course會教埋點樣用STATA。

Course Content:
1. Introduction to econometrics
2. Review of probability and statistics
3. Simple Linear Regression: Estimation （即係點做）
4. Simple Linear Regression: Inference （即係做完點分析）
個人認為Simple Linear嗰part even簡單過2411....
----------------Midterm-----------------
5. Multiple Regression: Estimation （基本上同Simple一樣，舉一反三）
6. Multiple Regression: Inference (又係同上面一樣咁濟...)
7. Non-linear Regression （時代革命同埋佢sem頭教得太慢cut埋，但睇落一啲都唔難，take下log，d下數咁）
8. A guide to empirical study （時代革命同埋佢sem頭教得太慢cut埋）

讀完真係好似無讀過咁，啲content係講緊你有basic stat個底去睇書可以一日自學晒，完全唔明啲prerequsite同4credits係jm9。
reviews.comment_teaching:
雖然content好唔掂，但lu xun教書教得唔差，個logic講得好清晰，同埋佢會make sure你明背後個intuition，而唔係淨係玩數學。但佢真係教得好L慢，一版powerpoint可能講緊joint probability，佢要講成20分鐘咁...同埋佢啲英文真係好唔掂，個accent好重，有啲一舊舊。我諗對一啲stat真係好差嘅人真係一個好好嘅professor，但對一啲有認真讀prerequisite嘅人嚟講都真係悶到抽筋。自己睇路走堂。另外佢會示範點樣用STATA，都係用電腦撳一次俾我地睇咁。

Tutorial 兩個星期先一次，懷疑個tutor都覺得無野教，上堂就做下exercise，計下啲tricky少少嘅數咁囉，唔上都無所謂，但佢啲notes都唔差嘅。
reviews.comment_grading:
考試都好正路，通常頭一兩題concepts，之後計下數，臨尾一兩題係啲簡單嘅proofs咁，concepts啲題目係真係要十分心水清，make sure你知晒啲terminology嘅definition同可能有無啲咩special case嘅examples之類啦。計數就簡單野，可能俾三點你計返條regression line出嚟，再計下啲相關嘅野，例如R square之類。proofs就反而係最simple嗰part，真係跟住啲formula砌就得，唔會要用啲好hardcore嘅math skills。Midterm一版cheat sheet，final兩版，基本上整得好就玩晒成個course。

Grading system:
6 Problem sets 15%
Midterm 30%
Final 55%

General Performance:
Problem set: basically full for everyone
Midterm: 74/100
Final: Unknown

My Performance:
Problem set: full
Midterm: 96/100
Final: Unknown

Final Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
基本上都叫無咩workload，6份 problem sets都好簡單，其實啲題目都好standard好類似，又唔算長，每份都3/4版字做得晒。後期嘅assignment要用stata撳下啲result去答，都ok唔算chur。

midterm final要時間去整cheat sheets，不過整完都算溫完。BTW唔好諗住臨考前幾個鐘先整，整唔晒架。

reviews.author: HcDaniel
reviews.comment_content: The course content is considered not being very hard, as long as you have built a strong foundation of regression analysis in the ISOM 2500 and ISOM 2600 course. Not much calculation is needed, if so, those calculations are rather easy. However, the midterm and final are very hard, it is another level comparing with the slide content.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor cares about every students' learning progress and taught the content at a moderate pace so that students were able to follow. I can see that he wanted to teach us more than only the course syllabus, but more practical knowledge and skills that might be useful for our future research. He is kind and helpful.
reviews.comment_grading: Since midterms and exams are very hard, you might still get good grades even if you scored low marks. But one can be reminded that if you attempt to get very good grades, you have to study real hard for that since some Year 2 & 3 ECOF students are preregistered into this course in the fall semester.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload. There are only 4 Assignments throughout the semester, and once you have done them you can get full marks (no matter you answered them correctly or wrongly). But it might takes some time to do each assignment (if you do it properly). It caused me a few hours for each assignment.

reviews.author: Gayauuuu
reviews.title: Passionate but POOR professor
reviews.comment_content:
Ch.1 Introduction
Ch.2 Probability
Ch.3 Review of Statistics
Ch.4 Linear Regressor with One Regressor
----------------------------------------------------
Ch.5 Robust Inference
Ch.6 Omitted Variable
Ch.7 Statistic Inference in Multiple Regression
Ch.8 Applications
Ch.9 Methods

Mid-term covers Ch.1-4; Final is cumulative.

95% of the contents are totally unrelated to Economics, and it's just like an advanced level of Isom 2500. If you are bad at Isom 2500 like me, good luck :)

During lessons, there are a lot of Maths and the usage of the software R, and the lectures are rather technical. But for the mid-term and final, only less than 30% of the questions required calculations and no R-related questions at all! So, the mid-term and final are a bit easier than I expected (, but they are still hard for me tho.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wang Peng is a passionate professor. I can tell from his email replying speed and he really tried his best to explain all the concepts to us.

BUTTT trying his best =/= doing a good job!!! To be honest, he taught really badly! Every time after attending his lecture, I don't know what have I learnt... And I want to review his PowerPoint, many concepts are compacted into one slide without any explanation.

Whenever I want to study this course, the recording and the PowerPoint will make me put this idea off...
reviews.comment_grading:
Not yet released the grade. I'll update it later.
-----------------------------------------------------
Update on 10/6:

Grading is not bad.
Homework (15%): Everyone will full
Mid Term (30%): Mean: ~16/30
Final (55%): Mean: ~60/100, sd: ~14

I've got a B eventually with full credit in homework; MT: 17/30;  Final: 55/100. I only step on the overall mean (or even slightly below), but I can still manage to get a B. So definitely good grading.

But bear in mind that many students in this class are from Ecof or Qfin. Econ students (aka me) are hard to compete with them and get a good grade. Worst still, Wang Peng's teaching is terrible, which makes us even harder to keep up with the Ecof and Qfin students. :(
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is super low. Only 4 exercises throughout the semester. And as long as you submit the assignments, you can get full credit, since they are graded by effort.

However, the content is very difficult for me. For each lecture, I spent on average 4-5 hours reviewing the recording/ searching YouTube videos or Google. Spending (or even wasting) so much time on a course that I don't like is just a torment... So, I can only give a C regarding the workload.

reviews.author: udontknowmyname
reviews.title: Excellent introductory econometrics course
reviews.comment_content:
Module 1 Introduction
Module 2 Review of Probability
Module 3 Review of Statistics
Module 4 Linear Regression with a Single Regressor: Estimation
Module 5 Linear Regression with a Single Regressor: Inference
-------------------------Midterm-------------------------
Module 6 Linear Regression with Multiple Regressors: Estimation
Module 7 Linear Regression with Multiple Regressors: Inference
Module 8 Linear Regression with Too Many Regressors: Big Data
Module 5 Linear Regression with a Single Regressor: Inference
---------------------------Final---------------------------
I think originally Prof. Feng planned to talk about some non-linear regression stuff but it was eventually cut. And I think he kind of rushed a bit on the big data part. But don't worry  because you are not expected to know much about big data.

To be honest, I expected this course to focus more on the mathematical tools of econometrics, but really it didn't. I wouldn't say I'm 100% satisfied with this but I have to say it makes sense since it's only an introductory course and many of the students don't have a solid foundation of math knowledge. So it's okay if your math is not so good. You can still do well in this course.
Many have compared this course with ISOM2500/2600, and some say that they are kind of similar. But my opinion is that even they use the same mathematical tools, their core idea is quite different. While ISOM2500/2600 focus on interpretation solely from mathematical results, this course introduces and focuses on the concept of "causal inference". I think it's vital to always keep that in mind to do well in this course.
And I think it's totally fine if you didn't do well in ISOM2500/MATH2411 since this course gives you a chance to "start over". Professor will start from the ground up to talk about some basic probability and statistics stuff.

The textbook for this course is Introduction to Econometrics by J. H. Stock and M. W. Watson. It's already sufficient to only know what's on lecture slides since the exam is exclusively based on them, but I think reading the textbook will give you a more solid understanding of econometrics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Junlong is a wonderful professor. I think he "got admitted" in UST at the same time as me which is 2 years ago lol. He graduated from Columbia and has a fluent American accent. He is very agreeable and always there to help students. You always get a quick reply from him when asking questions by email. He would add in his own understanding and some more "modern" stuff in lecture. He would also give us some tips that might be useful for our future study/research. As someone who just finished his postgraduate study I think he understands us a lot. And I think he's opinion on teaching and grading is quite "advanced" in this university. I must say that he can make my top 3 professor list in UST.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade hasn't been released yet. But according to what I know, I think Junlong would try his best to give us as good grades as possible.

The only thing to complain about the grading would be that the grading took almost a month.
reviews.comment_workload: Light especially for a 4 credit course. 4 assignments in total and nothing else, easy to finish. Some of them require you to write R codes.

reviews.author: Dreamscometrue
reviews.comment_content:
Starting from reviewing stuffs in introductory statistics, then move on to multiple regressions, non-linear regression.

Although the first part is review, more proofs are introduced than introductory level. I think those content are more difficult than the latter part.

The latter part can be digged into very deeap, but as we focus on application more, those difficult math are not covered. As a result, we are just substituting numbers into equations with a basic understanding towards the concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He teaches very well. Everything are explained clearly with easy examples. His teaching pace is very slow which makes everything pleasing. He will go through all the slides with you, so attending lesson helps shorten your revision time.

Also, he understands that some of us are not really good at maths, he try to focus on the concept and application. But for sure maths cannot be avoided.

55% final

The grading is fair in Econ deparment. Do not trust some sayings that he is strict in giving grades.

Scoring average in midterm is fine, you can catch up in final.

Final

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: The philosophy of doing Econometrics
reviews.comment_content:
The target of this course is how to study a causal effect of a treatment on the dependent variable.

1. Introduction
2. Probability Review
3. Statistics Review
Some of the things are not covered in Math2411/2421, and he will also introduce some terminology that are useful in this course, so don't skip it.

4. Linear Regression on Single Regressor
5. Robust Standard Error
6. Control Variables and Multiple Regressors
7. F-test
8. Application
Some real world examples are given.
9. Advanced Methods
Heterogeneous Causal Effects, Instrumental Variables, Difference-in-Differences.

This course focus on
1) the correctness of the model
2) the math part (inference step)

I would say wang peng put a lot of emphasis on the first part. In the final exam part 2 (56/100), there are a lot of these kinds of philosophical question:
- If the data generation process is like this, can we say that some population parameter is independent of another population parameter?
- Under different data generation process, can we believe that the OLS estimator is correctly describing the causal effect?

These questions are very hard to answer (or even search in net I think), it really test your understanding on the material of this course and how carefully you can think of to make sure the models are correct. It often requires insights on real life situation. Therefore, even you are good at the Math part, you still have to understand the art of Econometrics to ace this course (when Wang Peng is teaching).

I would say this arrangement is reasonable because an incorrect model leads to incorrect inference. The math part can be solved by machines easily today. So the job of Economists is to define a correct model. Actually, I appreciate such kind of art/philosophy of Econometrics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wang Peng is a very nice, kind gentleman, and he tries to provide as much help as possible to students.

I would say his teaching is quite good but the design of the content of lecture notes is bad.

Let's talk about his verbal delivery first. His English is quite good with light accent. One problem is that he never stress some points, meaning that he speaks everything at similar tone. He will speak the mathematical formulas directly which is difficult to listen to, e.g. variance of sum equals to sum of variance plus 2 times covariances. Luckily I got Zoom this year so that I can replay. Besides these things, I think his explanations are quite good.

But the flow of lecture notes is very bad.
Since I take Math2411 before and get destroyed by ycw. I really appreciate that the review part make me understand a lot more compared in Math2411.
However, starting at chapter 4, I lose my mind of the sudden change of topic. It is like I haven't attend to class for few weeks. A lot of notations that are quite confusing and some math equations that jumps out from nowhere.
For example, the average treatment effect E(Y_{1i} - Y_{0i}) is very confusing. I originally thought it is for a single person but it is actually the average effect on the whole population.
Another example: the mean independence requirement for OLS model: E(u|X) = 0 jumps out from nowhere. I can fully understand it after the chapter of control variables. It is used to prevent the "selection bias", meaning say people choosing particular treatment X may tends to have certain characteristics that affect our results.

I guess he intended to teach us all the theory part first, then it will be much easier (he thought) to learn to subsequent content. For example, in the first few slides of chapter 4, there is a slide talking about heterogeneous variance population model. It will be used in ch5 and ch9 later but he decided to put it earlier. That makes the lecture notes very difficult to understand as some slides are actually for more advanced topics.

Therefore, I am super confused in chapter 4 and everything gets clear after the whole chapter 6. You will understand more why he put a slide before when the course progress.

His lecture notes is not enough for revision, go to lesson and jot down some explanations or you will confused yourself through self-learning his notes.

reviews.comment_content:
Module 1. Introduction (Ch. 1)

Module 2. Review of Probability (Ch. 2)

Module 3. Review of Statistics (Ch. 3)

Module 4. Linear Regression with a Single Regressor: Estimation (Ch. 4)

Module 5. Linear Regression with a Single Regressor: Inference (Ch. 5)


Module 6. Linear Regression with Multiple Regressors: Estimation (Ch. 6)

Module 7. Linear Regression with Multiple Regressors: Inference (Ch. 7 & 9)

This design of this course is terrible. It focuses on rote memorization of econometric theories without practical applications. Professor Fung included R programming which was more useful but the main bulk of this course still revolved around pure recitation of facts. I believe this is a terrible way to learn. Econometrics has many useful applications in real life and it is a shame to see how the ECON department destroyed such a useful topic in economics. In fact, I was bored with the content that I didn't study for the midterms at all. This led to my low midterm score.

reviews.author: SNORLAX
reviews.title: Wang Pang's 3334 - a must take for all econ students
reviews.comment_content:
It covers:
Chapter1: introduction of economics
Chapter2: review of probability
Chapter3: review of statistics
Chapter4: simple linear regression
Chapter5: hypothesis test and confidence interval for simple linear regression
Chapter6: linear regression with multiple regressor
Chapter7: hypothesis testing and confidence interval in multiple regression
Chapter8: non-linear regression function
Chapter9: review on final exam

1/2 of the course content is covered in ISOM2500.
Before the mid term, all are review on ISOM2500. If you still remember the statistic and probability, you can get above mean if you spend some times on studying.

After the mid term, things are getting more difficult. But wp is willing teach much slower when I reported to him that we don't understand the lectures. He also spend the last two lectures on reviewing the final exam, so make sure you attend his last two lectures.

I know some students are complaining about the content is not enough, it looks like a 3-credit course rather than 4 credit.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I studied with 3 of econ and ecof friends. All of us think that his teaching is exceptionally good.
If you are econ students, you should take his course. You will learn a lot of advanced regression techniques (useful in modelling trend like stock and index).

He provides detailed and clear explanation on different concepts. Students with only ISOM2500 background (like me) also can get a good grade in his course, you just need to understand his teaching materials (lecture notes + what he said in class)

If you cannot catch up, you can watch his lecture video. He is very kind and provide all lecture videos on canvas.
